Most video games are well designed to capture and keep your attention. If you’re having a hard time concentrating, it’s because your mind really wants to think about something else. Next time you’re playing and you find yourself distracted, ask any or all of the following questions: What thoughts are coming?How do I feel physically?What emotions am I having?What is happening in my physical environment?What just happened in the video game?Take a pause from the game, as soon as you can, to answer these questions. Bonus points for writing about them. Repeat this cycle a few times, until you see a pattern in your thoughts, feelings, environment, or game interactions. Whatever that pattern is, that’s your major distraction. When you identify it, you can start to examine where it’s coming from. You can see what triggers it, and if it occurs in other areas of your life. And then, if you like you can make a change. Remove things that trigger distraction, practice reacting differently to the triggers, or having a different attitude. Maybe decide that this “distraction” is interesting enough in its own right that you plan time to think or deal with it for its own sake. Or just, notice that you get distracted by that thing and let it be. And for any who get distracting during other activities, you can use pretty much the same process. This is based on mindfulness and self-reflection practices, and it’s powerful stuff. If you start practicing it (even just while playing video games), it can change your life.
